PrimEcoSys: North American Warm Desert Bedrock Cliff and Outcrop

habitat_description:
Population occurrences have been reported to be confined to central Arizona (Leavitt et al. 2007; Sinclair et al. 2004). Previous to thorough phylogeographic studies, the range was thought to be restricted to an area near Sunflower, Maricopa County, Arizona (Pappenfuss et al. 2001). This is a species that occupies crevices in granite boulders in Arizona Upland Sonoran Desert and interior chaparral. It is found east of the Verde River from the Mazatzal Mountains and Superstition Mountains, Pinal Mountains, and across the Gila River to the Galiuro Mountains (Jones and Lovich 2009). 

The habitat occupied by this species is characterized mainly by granite outcrops where it is commonly found hiding under exfoliating rock (Papenfuss et al. 2001). Brennan and Holycross (2009) described this lizard as a secretive crevice dweller found in large outcroppings, cliff faces, and boulder fields within Arizona Upland Desertscrub, interior chaparral, and woodland communities.

Found in association to bare rock, talus and scree. Also found in decaying stool, and may also occur in decaying yuccas, saguaros, and agaves (Jones and Lovich 2009).
